title: Protocol to generate fast-dissociating recombinant antibody fragments for multiplexed super-resolution microscopy
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Construction of recombinant antibody
Timing: 4 days
      This part is for the construction of the mammalian expression vector for
      fluorescently labeled Fv-clasp and nanobodies. The mammalian expression
      plasmid for Fv-clasp (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) is constructed using
      a pcDNA3-based vector, containing a signal sequence from mouse IgH,11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]
      and a C-terminal 6xHis-tag.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2] The VH
      and VL are constructed in separate vectors. We fused an
      EGFP to the C-terminus of SARAH in the VH vector using AgeI
      site (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B). For single domain antibody (nanobody
      or VHH), we directly fused the EGFP to the C-terminus of nanobody (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).

        Subclone the VH and VL cDNA fragments of the
        antibody (see before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] for the
        identification and alignment of Fv).
        
Note: If you want to obtain the
          antibody sequence from mouse-derived antibody producing cells, use the
          following protocol for PCR cloning.
        
            Order the primer set below for PCR cloning. Premix and dissolve the
            primers to 10 μM in DDW for VH and VL,
            respectively.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_8.csv
            Extract the total mRNA of antibody producing cells using TRIzol
            Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 15596026).
          
            Reverse-transcript 0.5 μg of mRNA to synthesize cDNA (Total volume,
            10 μL) using ReverTra Ace qPCR RT Master Mix kit (Toyobo, FSQ-201).

Amplify the antibody cDNA by PCR with ExTaq polymerase (TaKaRa Ex
            Taq, RR001A).
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_9.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_10.csv
Subclone the antibody cDNA into pMD20 Vector (TaKaRa, 3270).
Obtain the antibody sequence using M13 Fw and Rv primer.
            Align the sequencing result using IgBlast tool and ANARCI web
            server.
          
        Insert the antibody Fv cDNAs into the expression vectors (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]
        B and 1C) using NotI and BamHI sites.
      
Note: Expression vectors for
      VH, VL and nanobodies are different (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B and 1C).
    
Purification of recombinant antibodies
Timing: 5 days
      It is necessary to evaluate the specificity and the dissociation rate of
      the antibodies that are obtained from databases. In this part, we describe
      a method for the production and purification of recombinant antibodies.
    
        Transfect HEK293T cells with the expression vector of recombinant
        antibodies.
        
Note: Antibody
          VH-SARAH-EGFP and VL-SARAH (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B) are co-transfected at a 1:1 molar ratio following the
          manufacture’s instruction of Lipofectamine 3000 Transfection Reagent
          Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, L3000015). The protocol is also used
          for the transfection of Nanobody-EGFP (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
        
            Grow HEK293T cells to be 80% confluent in two 10 cm petri dishes for
            the production of one antibody. Culture media, 10 mL.
          
            Dilute 30 μL Lipofectamine 3000 Reagent in 1.5 mL Opti-MEM (Thermo
            Fisher Scientific, 11058021) and vortex for 2–3 s (tube 1).
          
            Dilute 30 μg (15 μg VH-SARAH-EGFP + 15 μg
            VL-SARAH or 30 μg Nb-EGFP) DNA in 1.5 mL Opti-MEM
            separately, then add Opti-MEM containing 30 μL P3000 Reagent and mix
            well (tube 2).
            
Note: We found that 30 μL P3000
              Reagent is enough.
            
            Add the solution in tube 2 to tube 1 (DNA-lipid complex, ∼3 mL) and
            mix gently.
          
Incubate for 10 min at 15°C–25°C.
            Add 1.5 mL DNA-lipid complex to each 10 cm dish containing 10 mL
            culture medium.
            
Pause point: 3 days

Harvest the supernatant of the transfected cells 3–4 days after the
        transfection. Use one 15 mL falcon tube to collect the supernatant from
        one dish.
      
Note: Centrifuge the culture supernatant
      at 200×g for 3 min to spin down and remove the cell debris.
    
        Collect the 6×His tag fused recombinant antibodies with Ni-NTA agarose
        (QIAGEN, 30210).
        
            Prepare the agarose beads by washing 3 times with 1 mL TBS (repeat
            following steps ii to iiii for 3 times).
            
                Thoroughly suspend Ni-NTA agarose beads in stock and immediately
                transfer an appropriate amount of Ni-NTA resin to a 1.5 mL tube.
                Fifty μL of agarose beads are used for the purification of one
                antibody.
              
Add 1 mL TBS buffer.
                Centrifuge at 500 × g, 4°C for 5 min.
                
Note: The maximum resin
                  pressure resistance is 2.8 psi.
                
                Remove the supernatant. Be careful not to aspirate the beads.
              
Equilibrate the Ni-NTA beads by adding 5 bead volumes of TBS.
            Adjust the pH of harvested culture supernatant to 8.0 by adding 1 M
            Tris-HCL pH 8.0 (1%, v/v).
          
            Add 150 μL of equilibrated beads to the culture supernatant in each
            15 mL tube.
          
            Incubate with gentle rotation at 4°C for 2 h.
            
Critical: Protect the
              fluorescent antibodies from the exposure to light.
            
Pause point: 2 h.
            
        Wash the beads twice with TBS and once with TBS containing 10 mM
        imidazole.
      
        Elute the recombinant antibodies with 200 μL of 200 mM imidazole diluted
        in TBS buffer (pH 7.5) for 3 min on ice. Then, centrifuge at 500×g, 4°C
        for 5 min to spin down the beads. Collect 180 μL supernatant for
        dialysis.
      
        Dialyze the purified antibodies with 1 L TBS using 6–8 kD Spectra/Por
        membrane (Spectrum Laboratories, Inc., 132645) 20 h at 4°C. The TBS
        buffer is exchanged once 4 h after the first dialysis.

Pause point: 1 day.
    
        Measure the concentration of recombinant antibody by fluorescent
        intensity or Bradford protein assay (see
        expected outcomes[href=https://www.wicell.org#expected-outcomes] for the typical
        yield).
      
Note: Dispense, snap-freeze in liquid
      nitrogen and store the antibody solution at −80°C.
    
Evaluation of recombinant antibodies
Timing: 2 days
      The dissociation rate and specificity of purified antibody probes are
      evaluated using single-molecule approach as follows.
      Compared with conventional SPR, the single-molecule approach requires
        only a small amount of probes (∼1 pmol). Moreover, it enables to detect
        a minor fraction of probes with a wide range of detection limits (koff, 10−4–102 s−1). Xenopus XTC cells are utilized to express exogenous antigens
      because it is expected that endogenous proteins in XTC cells have limited
      cross-reactivity with antibody probes.
    
        Expression of corresponding antigens of antibodies in XTC cells (see
        before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] for the culture of XTC
        cells).
        
            Subclone the antigen cDNA in the MCS of the expression vector as
            shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]. The vector was constructed
            based on pEGFP-C1 (Clontech Laboratories, 6084-1). H2b-mCherry is
            co-expressed to identify the transfected cell.
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2940-Fig2.jpg
                  Figure 2. Map of vector for co-expressing antigen with
                  H2b-mCherry in eukaryotic cells
                
                  Antigen sequence is cloned into the MCS of the plasmid. The
                  vector was constructed based on pEGFP-C1 (Clontech
                  Laboratories, 6084-1).
                
            Transfect the XTC cells with antigens following manufacture’s
            protocol of Neon transfection system (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The
            parameters for electroporation are described below.12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]
table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_11.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_12.csv
            Culture the transfected XTC cells in 22°C incubators for ∼24 h.
            
Note: Subculture into a 25 cm2
              flask if the cells are used after >24 h.
            
Pause point: 1–2 days.
            
        Coat the coverslip with 0.1 mg/mL PLL (Sigma-Aldrich, 25988630, diluted
        in DDW) at 4°C for 16 h.
      
        Prepare the cell sample for single-molecule imaging.
        
            Trypsinize the transfected XTC cells and resuspend in L-15 (+)
            buffer.

Centrifuge at 200 × g for 3 min.
            Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell using L-15 (-) buffer.
          
            Seed the cells on PLL-coated coverslips in 6-well plates. Cell
            number, 2 × 104 per Φ24 mm coverslip.
            
Critical: PLL-coated
              coverslips should be rinsed at least 6 times by DDW before seeding
              the cells.
            
Culture the cells in 22°C incubators for 1 h.
            Fix the cells using 3.7% PFA buffer in Cytoskeleton buffer (see
            materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for
            the composition) at 15°C–25°C for 20 min.
            
Note: Add 0.5% Tx-100 in case the
              fraction of the antigens in the cytoplasm needs to be removed.
            
Note: The Cytoskeleton buffer is
              used to preserve the structure and organization of the actin
              cytoskeleton especially when cells are fixed in the presence of
              detergents. It should be used with caution to study other cellular
              structures.
            
            Wash 3 times with PBS and permeabilize the cells using PBS
            containing 0.2% Tx-100 (v/v).
          
            Block the sample for 1 h at 15°C–25°C using 3% BSA (w/v) in PBS
            buffer.
          
Wash the sample 3 times with PBS before imaging.
        Acquire the single-molecule time-lapse images of bound antibodies in
        transfected cells.
        
            Dilute the recombinant antibodies to 0.1–0.5 nM in imaging buffer
            (see
            materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for
            the composition).
            
Critical: The concentration of
              antibody probes should be determined by the density of
              single-molecule speckles so that target proteins in the cells can
              be sparsely labeled (typically, 0.1–0.5 speckles/μm2,
              see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). The density of the speckles is
              proportional to the concentration of the fluorescent antibodies
              bound to the targets.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2940-Fig3.jpg
                  Figure 3. Demonstration for single-molecule imaging
                
                  (A) Demonstration for the speckle densities in single-molecule
                  imaging (unit, speckles per μm2). Many speckles are
                  overlapped with each other and cannot be distinguished when
                  the density is higher than 0.5/μm2. Scale bar,
                  5 μm.

(B) A transfected XTC cell co-expressing antigen with
                  H2b-mCherry. Scale bar, 10 μm.
                
                  (C) Single-molecule imaging of the antigen expressed in
                  (B) using 250 pM Fv-clasp-EGFP. The left panel in (C) is the
                  same imaging region with (B). The right panel in (C) is the
                  enlarged image of boxed region in left panel. Scale bar, 5 μm.
                
            Find a transfected cell expressing H2B-mCherry (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
          
            Switch to the GFP channel and check if the density of speckles in
            the cell is suitable for single-molecule imaging (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
            
Note: If there is no binding probe
              or the density of binding probes are not substantially higher than
              in non-transfected XTC cells, the probe is not specific enough to
              recognize the antigen.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: As mentioned above, the
              typical density is 0.1–0.5 speckles/μm2. For the
              analysis of dissociation rate, the speckle number in the imaging
              field should be more than 100.
            
            Acquire time-lapse image series of bound single-molecules in the
            cell.
            
Note: Total Internal Reflection
              Fluorescence (TIRF) illumination can be used to reduce the
              background signals.
            
Critical: Acquisition speed of
              time-lapse imaging should match with the antibody kinetics.
              Generally, time intervals should be no more than 1/2 of the
              antibody half-lives (T1/2 = ln2 / koff).
              Typically, we acquire 60–100 frames with 5–30 s time interval to
              measure the dissociation rate of wild-type antibodies with koff
              of 10−2–10−4 s−1.
            
Optional: In the time-lapse
              imaging with time interval longer than 20 s, a BF image should be
              recorded following each exposure for the compensation of stage
              drift.
            
        Track the single-molecule using software such as tanitracer4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4],10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10] (https://github.com/takushim/tanitracer[href=https://github.com/takushim/tanitracer]).
      
Optional: Use tanipoc.py in
      Tanitrancer to correct the stage drift during the acquisition using BF
      images described in Step 13d.
    
        Calculate the dissociation rate (koff) using a
        one-phage-decay model.

Output the regression of speckles detected in the first frame using
            tanitime.py in Tanitracer. The result is summarized in a file named
            as File-name_regression.txt, see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for the
            example of a raw data set.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_13.csv
Note: Type the following command
              to output the list of regression:
            
> tanitime.py -x time-interval File-name.txt
            Copy the “Lifetime” and “Regression” column to GraphPad Prism 9 and
            analyze the data using “Nonlinear Regression” > “one-phase-decay”
            model (www.graphpad.com/guides/prism/latest/curve-fitting/reg_exponential_decay_1phase.htm[href=http://www.graphpad.com/guides/prism/latest/curve-fitting/reg_exponential_decay_1phase.htm]). The best-fit K (hereafter called KR) and Half-life
            values are shown in the results. The black “WT” curve in
            Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] is the fitting to the data in
            Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1].
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2940-Fig4.jpg
                  Figure 4. Demonstration for amino acid substitutions at
                  candidate sites in 12CA5 antibody, which increases the
                  dissociation rate by orders of magnitude
                
                  See Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for the source data of WT
                  curve. The regression of speckles was fitted using one phase
                  decay model in Prism 9.
                
Critical: Set the Plateau of
              curve constant equal to 0 in the “Constrain” tab.
            
            Measure the photobleaching rate (Kp) of fixed EGFP in XTC
            cells.
            
                Express EGFP-actin in XTC cells and fix the cells with 3.7% PFA
                buffer containing 0.2% Tx-100. Then, wash the cell 3 times with
                PBS buffer.
              
                Acquire the time-lapse images for EGFP regression.
                
Note: The time-interval,
                  exposure time and laser power for acquiring EGFP regression
                  should be kept the same as those used for fluorescent
                  antibodies.
                
                Calculate the intensity of EGFP in each frame.
                
Note: Background should be
                  subtracted from the fluorescent intensity.
                
                Fit the regression curve of EGFP fluorescent intensity using a
                one-phase-decay model. The best fitted K value represents the
                photobleaching rate (Kp).
              
            Calculate the dissociation rate (koff) by subtracting
            Kp from KR.
          
Site-directed mutagenesis
Timing: 4 days – 2 weeks
    
      To accelerate the dissociation rate of the recombinant antibodies, several

conserved amino acids located at the base of antibody CDR loops are
      identified as candidate sites for Ala (A) or Gly (G) substitution.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
      This section outlines the principles for selecting the combination of
      substitution sites and includes the method for site-directed mutagenesis.
    
        Align the antibody sequence and identify the candidate sites for
        mutagenesis (see before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] for
        the alignment of antibody sequence).
      
Note: Candidate sites are: H27, H28, H32,
      H59 and H102 for antibody VH; L32, L49 and L96 for antibody
      VL; Nb27, Nb28, Nb32, Nb37, Nb59 and Nb102 for nanobodies.
      These candidate sites are highly conserved in antibodies and
      nanobodies.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
        Generate 3–5 antibody mutants with a single amino acid substitution at
        candidate sites.
        
Note: As a starting point, we
          recommend trying the following substitutions: H/Nb32A, H/Nb59A, Nb37A,
          L32A, L49A and L96A. Mutations at these sites could effectively
          accelerate the dissociation rate but occasionally lead to the loss of
          antigen recognition.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] A concise
          protocol for DpnI-mediated site-directed mutagenesis is described as
          follows.
        
            Design the forward and reverse primer for the reaction.
            
Note: The primer sequences should
              be complementary to each other. The primer should be 14–18 base
              pairs (bp) long on both sides of the mutation site, and terminate
              with a G or C. The melting temperature (Tm) should be between
              55°C–65°C.
            
            Introduce the point mutation by PCR reaction:
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_14.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_2940_15.csv
            Digest methylated plasmid template with DpnI (New England Biolabs,
            R0176S) for 90 min.
          
            Transform the mutated plasmid into competent E. coli DH5α.
          
        Purify the antibody mutants and measure the dissociation rates using the
        procedures described in steps 3–15.
      
Note: As an example, single point
      mutations HY32A and LY49A in 12CA5 antibody (anti-hemagglutinin [HA] tag)
      fragments increase the dissociation rate by 36 folds and 2.4 folds,
      respectively (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: Some antibodies may lose the antigen

recognition after the mutagenesis. The substitution sites in those
      antibody mutants should be avoided in the following steps which combine
      multiple point mutations.
    
        Combine two point mutations in VH and VL to
        further increase the dissociation rate (e.g., H32A + L49A in
        Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
      
        Introducing an additional H/Nb27G, H/Nb28A or H/Nb102A substitution
        could further increase the dissociation rate with a high probability
        (e.g., H28A + H32A + L49A in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
      
Note: The desired half-life for antibody
      probes in IRIS super-resolution imaging is typically between 1–10 s. In
      general, it is recommended to only introduce 1–5 point mutations to the
      antibody as introducing too many mutations sometimes results in increased
      noise levels.
